extraAttributes.definitions: Amounts of space establish for development of design scenarios
Spaces planned to perform a function in support of the occupant business objectives.
Spaces planned to support the operation of the building enabling the occupants to work in a safe and supportive environment.
Spaces planned to be provided as a convenience offering occupants support beyond their business driven functional requirements.
Spaces planned for circulation to provide or control access to and between other spaces within the facility, entry, and egress.
Spaces planned to be used to circulate and station vehicles.
A space inside the building where floor structure might otherwise be expected. The lowest floor of a multi-story void is classified based on the utilization at that level.
Multi-story, enclosed space in a building, which may have a skylight. Every level of the atrium
a vertical (or near vertical) shaft that supplies ventilation to a tunnel or other underground facility
Opening in a floor created for the specific benefit of an occupant.

The space taken up by any of various permanent upright constructions having a length much greater than the thickness and presenting a continuous surface except where pierced by doors, windows, etc.: used for shelter, protection, or privacy, or to sub
a structure that creates the separation necessary to enclose a building. (derived from BOMA definition)
The space of a wall that divides/separates inside spaces only. The wall may be structural or non-structural
The space associated with base building elements that prevent the use of the space for furniture, equipment, circulation, or other occupant function.
The space associated with a base building element that is located inside the building but not on the outer wall.
The space associated with a base building element that is located on the outer wall.
Spaces used to circulate and station vehicles.

Outdoor area used for transient storage of motor vehicles, not including loading docks, sally ports and building service areas such as enclosed auxiliary lobbies used to enter a building from parking areas.
Outdoor space used to circulate vehicles and providing access to parking stalls.
Outdoor parking access control point space such as attendant booth, gate, card reader, or self serve ticket dispenser.
Outdoor space provided for parking a vehicle (car, truck, bicycles or motorbikes).
Totally or partially enclosed space that is normally used to circulate and station vehicles.
Interior space including ramps used to circulate vehicles and providing access to parking stalls.
Interior parking access control point space such as attendant booth, gate, card reader, or self serve ticket dispenser.
Interior space provided for parking a vehicle (car, truck, bicycles or motorbikes).
Interior parking stall and circulation space used to provide vehicle services.
portion of a building that provides services that enable occupants to work in a building
opening in a floor that serves a building or system distribution function
Space used by mechanical modes of circulation such as elevators and escalators providing transportation between floors of a structure.
An enclosed space extending through one or more stories of a building connecting vertical openings in successive floors, or floors and the roof used to enclose an elevator.
Platform or an enclosure raised and lowered in a vertical shaft to transport people or freight.
A room to house elevator motors, pumps, controls or lifting equipment
A small lift / elevator used to move food etc. from one floor of a building to another.
Set of moving steps attached to a continuously circulating belt that carries people up or down between levels in a building.
Device for vertical transportation of freight to different floors or levels in a building
Space used by a static circulation path providing transportation between floors of a structure.
A stair that is part of an exit or leads to an exit.
A stair that is accessible only by the tenant
Space occupied by a larger than necessary, architectural stair. Space with clear headroom under the stair may be classified differently.
A walking surface that has a running slope steeper than 1 unit vertical in 20 units horizontal (5-percent slope). (IBC)
a primarily vertical enclosure containing one or more passageways for conveying flue gasses to the outside atmosphere.
(postal, refuse, laundry) which end at a 'termination room' - a shaft enclosure that does not extend to the underside of the roof sheathing, deck, or slab of the building.

Space used to accommodate intra-floor services such as flues, fire towers, fire hose cabinets (because of the pipes attached to them), stacks, pipe shafts, electricity, vertical air conditioning ducts and other vertical ducts.
A vertical service pipe or duct providing a route for electrical cabling to service floors with electricity
A vertical service pipe or duct providing a route for communication cabling to service floors with tele and/or data communications
A vertical service pipe or duct providing a route for gas piping to service floors with gas.
A vertical service pipe or duct providing a route for piping to service floors with water and/or other liquids

Space solely used to accommodate horizontal distribution of infrastructure for HVAC, Power and Communications. Within Interstitial space the tracking of horizontal distribution is optional. Generally the final distribution such as electrical circuits
A horizontal space providing a route to distribute electricity on a floor
A horizontal space providing a route to distribute tele and/or data communications on a floor
A horizontal space providing a route to distribute gas on a floor
A horizontal space providing a route to distribute water and/or other liquids on a floor
Space used for the control and monitoring of life safety and communication services.
Space for fire department operations with the location, layout, content and features and approved by the fire department; includes Fire Protection System (FPS)
Booth or room within building line used to house security for building or tenant.
A secondary building entrance space used to accommodate shipping and delivery of bulk materials to the structure.
A space with washing and toilet facilities.
Toilet(s) used exclusively by men.
Toilet(s) used exclusively by women.
Public toilet for individual use by either men or women

Space provided for the general operation of heating, ventilating, and air conditioning, plumbing and electrical, life safety and communication services; including sections of tunnels which are dedicated to distribution of utilities.
A room meeting prescribed safety requirements and in which refrigeration systems or components thereof are located.
A room primarily utilized for the installation of fuel-burning, space-heating and water-heating appliances other than boilers.
A room used for reducing combustible refuse material to ashes.
A separately ventilated, fully enclosed room for the storage of fuel
A separately ventilated, fully enclosed room in which only compressed gases and associated equipment and supplies are stored or used
A room classified as a Group H-3 occupancy used for the storage of flammable or combustible liquids in a closed condition

level3.title: Liquid Use, Dispensing and Mixing Room

extraAttributes.definitions: A room in which Class I, II, and IIIA flammable or combustible liquids are used, dispensed or mixed in open containers
an assembly of piping, devices and apparatus designed to generate, store, contain, distribute or transport a nontoxic, gaseous hydrogen containing mixture
A designated room containing electrical equipment.
Contains electrical switch gear and equipment.
A designated room containing telecommunications equipment.
A separately ventilated, fully enclosed room to house the building power transformer
Space used for holding garbage and recyclable materials.
An area used for the storage of chemicals or substances that pose a physical or health hazard that are in waste condition.
Other building service space, such as space used for the building operator and custodian office, workshop and supplies.
Space for the property manager
Room that contains sink(s) or mop sink(s) and is used by custodial services for CUST. their related activities.
A place where things are crafted
Space that leads to prefabricated sewage system 'man hole' structures
A subsurface space adjacent to a building open at the top or protected at the top by a grating or guard
Clear floor space in front of an appliance to assure adequate space for servicing.
Furred-out space is created when the floor layout must accommodate irregular wall surfaces or conceal mechanical obstructions.
Unexcavated space that has restricted headroom and is not occupiable.
The space between the ceiling beams of the top story and the roof rafters.
A horizontal chamber intended to contain air, gas, or liquid at positive pressure

An unoccupied elevated platform used exclusively for mechanical systems or industrial process equipment, including the associated elevated walkways, stairs and ladders necessary to access the platform.

The area of load bearing surfaces located above or below occupied building floor that are not available for general occupancy often due to inadequate clear headroom and contain building mechanical or electrical systems predominantly serving the adjac
The portion of a building that has been constructed with minimal enclosure for future use.
Spaces temporarily out of use because they are being altered, remodeled, or rehabilitated at the time of the inventory.
Spaces for circulation that provide or control access to and between other spaces within the facility, entry, and egress.
The direct path on a floor necessary for access to egress stairs, elevator lobbies, toilet rooms, refuge space, building lobbies and entrances.
An enclosed exit access component that defines and provides a path of egress travel to an exit.
An exit access component that defines and provides a path of egress travel.
A roofed or covered common pedestrian area within a covered mall building that serves as access for two or more tenants.
A large open space in a building where people can gather.
A structure with a roof and open sides that connects two buildings.
A slow conveyor belt that transports people horizontally or on an incline in a similar manner to an escalator.
Space adjacent to the entry points such as lobbies.
A passage, hall or room between the outer door and the interior of a building
A large entrance area of hall that serves as a foyer
Entranceway or foyer within the building line.
A small passage, hall, or room between a door or room and another room, corridor, or lobby
Lobby that separates the elevator shaft enclosure doors from each floor by fire partitions.
A small passage, hall, or room between a door or room and a freight elevator.
An in-between platform or large bottom-most or top-most step of a staircase
A room before, or forming an entrance to, another

An airlock is a device which permits the passage of people and objects between a pressure vessel and its surroundings while minimizing the change of pressure in the vessel and loss of air from it. The lock consists of a small chamber with two airtigh
A small controlled space with two doors. Access requires that one door must remain closed to proceed, used for security.
An enclosed, telescoping, movable ramplike bridge connecting an airport terminal and an aircraft, for use by passengers in boarding and disembarking.
A covered or enclosed bridge, walk-way, tunnel or other similar connecting element between two separate buildings.
Unenclosed corridors meeting circulation and exiting requirements of the local building code, and only when there are no fully enclosed corridors on a Floor that provide that function..
A portion of a floor required for access to some subdivision of the floor, that does not serve all occupants on a floor, and is not defined as primary circulation Space.
A recess in a vertical wall plane that contains an access and egress to a tenant area, or amenity area, or building service area.
Space that is normally available for use but is set aside by regulatory authority, such as clear space requirements for electrical closets.
An enclosed space that is protected from the effects of fire permitting a delay in required egress travel time.
Space used for education.
A space associated with a classroom or training room that is designated for discussions, side meetings, and breaks.
Spaces used for classes, lectures, symposiums, and speeches.
A room in which teaching or learning activities can take place.
A room in which teaching or learning activities can take place for older children, ages 9 and over.
A room in which teaching or learning activities can take place for younger children, ages 8 and younger.
A large room used for instruction, typically at a college or university, with a capacity in the hundreds.
A hall where many students and teachers can congregate.
A space for conducting a course offered for a small group of advanced students.

A space used primarily for formally or regularly scheduled instruction that require special purpose equipment or a specific space configuration for student participation, experimentation, observation, or practice in an academic discipline.
An educational space that provides controlled conditions in which scientific research, experiments, and measurement may be performed for teaching purposes.
An educational laboratory space for teaching physics through hands on experimentation and demonstration.
An educational laboratory space for teaching astronomy through hands on experimentation and demonstration. May require a planetarium and rooftop observation platforms.

A space used for laboratory experimentation, research, or training in research methods; professional research and observation; or structured creative activity within a specific program or for sponsored research.
A space that directly serves one or more class laboratories as an extension of the activities in those spaces.
A space that directly serves one or more class laboratories as an extension of the activities in those spaces.
A space that directly serves one or more class laboratories as an extension of the activities in those spaces.
Space that is similar in configuration to a classroom but which contains specialized equipment or machinery used as part of a specific training activity.

Space, often found in libraries, schools, government buildings, science labs, or community centers, which contains many networked computers and may contain printers, scanners, or other peripherals for public use.
A room for providing vocational education and training in the skills needed to perform a particular job, such as wood or metal working.
Space which is used for support services directly related to training activities.
Space for training of those who perform or administer religious rites, both laypeople and clergy.
Spaces in which learning or experimentation take place.
A room or area used by individuals to study at their convenience, the space not being restricted to a particular subject or discipline by contained equipment.
A space that directly serves study spaces, stacks, open-stack study spaces, or processing rooms as a direct extension of the activities in those spaces. stack and study areas.
A space for any leisure activity, such as play, that diverts, amuses or stimulates.
Spaces for participating in sports and athletic activities.
The covered seating area used by students, staff, or the public to watch athletic events.
A seating section commonly found in athletic spaces but occasionally found in performance spaces, containing bench seating instead of separate seats.
Spaces for participating in team sports and athletic activities.
A playing field on which the game of baseball is played.
A playing field on which the game of softball is played. See also Baseball Field
A sunken shelter at the side of a baseball or football (soccer) field where non-playing team members sit.
A grass field on which a game, esp. a ball game, is played.
A field, often used for team sports, planted with a synthetic grass substitute.
A playing field on which the game of American football is played. Also used as an informal measurement of size.
A playing field on which the game of soccer is played.
A concreted outside area or tiled or wooden inside area on which the game of basketball is played.
Spaces for lighting equipment used to illuminate a team sport playfield.
The section in a stadium or arena set aside for the press, or specifically for sportscasters.
A large board that displays the score in a game or contest.
Spaces for participating in individual sports and athletic activities.
Hard-surfaced spaces used for individual or team recreation, such as playgrounds.
A firm, rectangular surface, marked with lines and having a net across the middle, where the game of tennis is played.
A rectangular surface marked with lines and having a high net across the middle, where the game of volleyball is played.
A grassy course consisting of series of holes, each with a teeing ground, fairway, rough and other hazards, and a green with a pin and cup, all designed for the game of golf.
A facility for practicing driving golf balls.
Spaces designed to support golf courses on the installation. Space may include equipment storage and maintenance areas, locker rooms, and equipment sales area.
A specially frozen surface of water on which people skate or play ice hockey.
A space, usually square, with elastic ropes around the edge, in which a boxing match is competed.
A space in which a wrestling match is competed.
A springboard used for diving into water
A space in which players attempt to score points by rolling a bowling ball along a flat surface into objects called pins.
A space in which darts can be thrown at a circular target (dartboard) hung on a wall.
A space for interval training in which strength exercises are combined with endurance/aerobic exercises.
A track for holding running events at track and field competitions.
Space for a device that transports skiers up a mountain.
A space to perform physical activity intended to improve strength and fitness.
A space for a machine designed to enable exercise to enhance or maintain physical fitness and overall health.
A space for a form of exercise, designed to enhance one's cardiovascular fitness, often performed to music.
An artificial wall used for the sport of climbing.
A challenging outdoor personal development and team building activity which usually consists of elements of varying height connected by rope bridges that must be traversed.
Non-enclosed swimming pools intended for recreational use. See also: Indoor Swimming Pool
An artificially enclosed body of water intended for swimming or water-based recreation, designed for year-round use. See also: Outdoor Swimming Pool
A water-filled structure for training related to SCUBA diving.
Spaces for recreation and entertainment that do not include athletic activity or sports.

A tract of ground kept in its natural state, about or adjacent to a residence, as for the preservation of game, for walking, riding, or the like or a piece of ground, in or near a city or town, enclosed and kept for ornament and recreation; as, Hyde

A garden that is opened to the public for recreation, differentiated from other public gardens by containing entertainments in addition to the planting; for example, concert halls or bandstands, rides, zoos or menageries.
Indoor firing ranges provide marksmanship training space for the firing of pistols and small caliber rifles.
A training range for the firing of small arms

Wood or timber flat surface capable of supporting weight and used in a number of ways - as part of garden landscaping, to extend living areas of houses, and as an alternative to stone based features such as patios.
A large open space where children play or small area for children with dedicated play equipment - slide, or tubes, or swings, etc.
A room used for a variety of purposes, such as parties, games and other everyday or casual use.
A table where games of chance such as poker, craps, or roulette are played and bet upon.
A device found at carnivals, fairs/funfairs, or amusement parks meant to appeal to various senses of the rider.
A large area of hard ground, usually of concrete or tarmac, where soldiers practice routine marching maneuvers.
A space for projecting an apparent reality that is only based in the computer.
A facility that provide space for administration, drawing and art studio, storage, photo dark room, audio/photo sales area, separate areas for individual crafts and arts, and kiln area for ceramics.
A dance floor construction, which may include a sprung floor, flooring typically made of vinyl sheeting, also called a marley floor, or an illuminated dance floor, also called a disco dance floor.
Space that is related to medical and other wellness services provided to the personnel in a facility; such as first aid stations.
Spaces for exercise and fitness activities.
Space used for physical wellness but does not include weight-lifting equipment
Space used for weight-lifting, either using exercise equipment or free weights.
A place provided for general public access and use.
Spaces supporting the work of the justice system.
The room where a judge presides over hearings and trials, sometimes with a jury
The area in a courtroom wherein the jury is seated during a trial.
The room where a jury is sequestered and deliberates at the close of a trial.
The location in a courtroom where a judge sits.
Room used to secure legal evidence, usually near a courtroom.
Room where prospective jurors gather to wait or assemble before being selected for jury duty. Includes seating area and may include TV, work stations, and tables.
An enclosed area in a courtroom where witnesses give their evidence.
The office of a judge.

Space with features exceeding typical office space standards such as extensive wood millwork, wood base, chair rail, fabric wall covering, vinyl wall covering, sound board, speakers, CCTV monitors and/or cameras, panic buttons, recessed can lighting,
Space for a law clerk that assists a judge.
Space for judges to change into their robes.
Room used by courts and administrative agencies as a location where evidence and testimony is submitted for findings of fact.

Small court facilities that typically have features such as column spacing less than 30Â’-0Â” on center, above-standard lighting and HVAC, built-in judgeÂ’s bench, chair rail, sound system, recessed can lighting, separate air, walls-to-deck crown moldin
Spaces supporting the legislative assemblies of government.
A specialized meeting space generally associated with local government facilities. The space is designed to allow councilors to interact face to face and includes gallery space for citizens.

Room where members of legislative bodies and their committees and subcommittees hold hearings for receipt of testimony and evidence in reference to action on legislation. Typically has audience space.
Spaces associated with Military training functions
A room or area used by Reserve Officer Training Corps (ROTC) and ancillary units for military training and/or instructional activities.
A space that directly serves an armory facility as an extension of the activities in that facility.
Space used for any performance type such as dance, music or theater.
An outdoor facility to accommodate cultural events such as plays, concerts, and festivals.
A space for events in which performers perform for an audience.
A space for the performance of theatrical productions.
The area in a theater, usually located in a lowered area in front of the stage, in which musicians perform.
A space for conducting preparatory music and theatre performances before the official public performance.
A soundproof, hangar-like space used for the production of theatrical motion pictures and television shows, usually located in a movie studio.

A room or theater, often with tiers of seats, which serves as performance venue, such as for classical instrumental music or jazz, or for hearing lectures or presentations. Includes amphitheaters, auditoriums, or concert halls.
Space for marching band rehearsal.
Spaces for a group of people who observe a performing art.
A room used for entry from the outside in a building that houses performing arts productions, and in which the audience can gather before showtime and at intermission.
A space where audience members can sit during a performance.
Spaces used to provide support to any performance type such as dance, music or theater.
Space in a movie theater that houses the projector and other equipment used to show the movie.
An elevated walkway in a theater or soundstage used to access rigging for lights, curtains, sets, and other items.
Areas adjacent to the stage in a theater, where support personnel and players can stand.
Space for a motion picture screen and associated equipment.
Areas for the display of art and other exhibit materials
A room, group of rooms, or other space where works of art are placed on display, possibly for sale.
A space for a public showing or exhibition of items of interest.
An outdoor garden dedicated to the presentation of sculpture, usually several permanently-sited works in durable materials in landscaped surroundings.
A planned space, usually outdoors, set aside for the display, cultivation, and enjoyment of ornamental plants and flowers.
A platform situated upon a tall architectural structure or natural feature.
Space fit-up with features facilitating the production of art and/or the broadcasting, recording, editing or storage of audio visual productions.
Space fit-up to facilitate the recording of sounds
Space fit-up to facilitate the development of works of art
Space fit-up to facilitate the production and/or repair of film and electronic photography
Space for the distribution of motion picture prints for viewing by military personnel.
Space fit-up with features facilitating the production of televised programming live or recorded.
Space supporting media production such as make-up station, dressing room, guess waiting room, wardrobe/prop room
Room that provides an acoustical buffer to eliminate the transfer of sound to adjoining space.
An enclosed shallow sandpit containing sand, gravel, rocks, and occasionally grass and/or other natural elements, raked and arranged artfully, usually providing a quiet, contemplative setting.
A space in a museum for the exhibition, and educational interpretation of objects having scientific, historical, cultural or artistic value.
Space in which literary, musical, artistic, or reference materials (as books, manuscripts, recordings, or films) are kept for use but not for sale.
A space used to house arranged collections of literary, musical, artistic, educational or reference materials for use.
Space designated for the practice of religion or meditation .
Spaces for conducting worship activities, such as prayer, religious or spiritual ceremonies or celebration, or meditation.
A space provided for obtaining a deeper state of relaxation or awareness.
A space upon which offerings can be made for religious purposes, or some other sacred place where ceremonies take place.
A space for self-observation and contemplation of conscious inner thoughts, desires and sensations.
A space for infusion of something with holiness or divine will.
A space used as a place for fellowship and worship for Christians.
A niche in the wall of a mosque that indicates the direction of the Kaaba in Mecca and hence the direction that Muslims should face when praying.
A holy or sacred place which is dedicated to a specific deity, ancestor, hero, martyr, saint or similar figure of awe and respect, at which they are venerated or worshipped.
The consecrated area of a church or temple around its tabernacle or altar.
A small, enclosed booth used for the Sacrament of Penance, often called confession, in the Catholic Church.
A cabinet used to store a synagogue's Torah scroll.
The elevated area or platform in a Jewish synagogue where the person reading aloud from the Torah stands.
A case on the altar of a church that contains the consecrated host and wine for the Eucharist.
A raised platform in a church, usually enclosed, where the minister or preacher stands to conduct the sermon.
A narrow recessed balcony area along an upper floor on the interior of a church, usually marked by a colonnade.
A space for performing a ceremony to change the religious nature or status of a person.
A space for conducting marriage ceremonies.
The area in a church surrounding the baptismal font.
A space in a religious structure for performing circumcisions.
The space surrounding the chair or throne of a bishop.
A space for performing a spiritual procession or orderly gathering and movement.
Spaces for religious and other proceedings surrounding death, funerals, and internment.
A chambered burial vault used to store the deceased.
A facility for the identification, preparation, and holding of human remains.
A room used for the storage of human remains awaiting identification, or removal for autopsy, burial, cremation or some other post death ritual.
A place where a dead body is buried.
Space with environments where such variables as humidity, temperature, pressure, sound, contamination are tightly controlled. These Spaces may be part of the research or production processes.

Space that is isolated from external sound and electromagnetic radiation sources, using sound proofing and electromagnetic absorptive material to prevent the reflection of wave phenomena (reverberation).
Specialized containment space for hazardous agents such as biological, radiological and chemical hazards.
Space in which the air quality, temperature and humidity are highly regulated in order to protect sensitive equipment and materials from contamination.
The ISO 14644-1 classification describes Clean rooms rated as 'Class 1,' where there exists no more than 10 particles larger than 0.1 micrometer in any given cubic meter of air;
The ISO 14644-1 classification describes Clean rooms rated as 'Class 2,' where there exists no more than 100 particles larger than 0.1 micrometer in any given cubic meter of air;
The ISO 14644-1 classification describes Clean rooms rated as 'Class 3,' where there exists no more than 1,000 particles larger than 0.1 micrometer in any given cubic meter of air;
The ISO 14644-1 classification describes Clean rooms rated as 'Class 4,' where there exists no more than 10,000 particles larger than 0.1 micrometer in any given cubic meter of air;
The ISO 14644-1 classification describes Clean rooms rated as 'Class 5,' where there exists no more than 100,000 particles larger than 0.1 micrometer in any given cubic meter of air;
The ISO 14644-1 classification describes Clean rooms rated as 'Class 6,' where there exists no more than 1,000,000 particles larger than 0.1 micrometer in any given cubic meter of air;
The ISO 14644-1 classification describes Clean rooms rated as 'Class 7,' where there exists no more than 10,000,000 particles larger than 0.1 micrometer in any given cubic meter of air;
The ISO 14644-1 classification describes Clean rooms rated as 'Class 8,' where there exists no more than 100,000,000 particles larger than 0.1 micrometer in any given cubic meter of air;
The ISO 14644-1 classification describes Clean rooms rated as 'Class 8,' where there exists no more than 1,000,000,000 particles larger than 0.1 micrometer in any given cubic meter of air;
Support space for a classified room but not enclosed within a classified room.
Space in which air or other gases can be added or removed to create low/ high air pressure environments. Chambers can also control the thermal environment.
Space designed to accommodate the needs of large quantities of co-located computer equipment.

Redundant Capacity Components with single path distribution systems.
Concurrently Maintainable Infrastructure which provides redundant capacity and multiple distribution paths.
Fault Tolerant Infrastructure providing redundant capacity and multiple distribution paths simultaneously serving dual powered equipment.
Support space for a Data Center but not enclosed within a Data Center.
Space designed to accommodate the needs of large quantities of co-located computer equipment.
Basic Site Structure providing non-redundant capacity and single path distribution systems.
Redundant Capacity Components with single path distribution systems.
Concurrently Maintainable Infrastructure which provides redundant capacity and multiple distribution paths.
Fault Tolerant Infrastructure providing redundant capacity and multiple distribution paths simultaneously serving dual powered equipment.
Support space for a Data Center but not enclosed within a Data Center.
Support space directly involved with environmentally controlled spaces.
Other Environmentally Controlled space not readily classified in one of the other classes.
Space fit-up with climate controls and storage equipment to facilitate the preservation of film
Climate controlled space for servers associated with office environments

Space which is used for services directly related to the heath care and medical practice. Most uses are applicable to providing medical care to humans as well as veterinarian services for animals. Size of the space may vary according to the size of t
Spaces used by multiple medical services for routine patient examinations.

Space used for routine, urgent, and emergent examination (physical inspection of a patient or parts of his body) in order to verify health or diagnose disease or injury. May also be Space used for minor procedures such as injections, wound care, and
Space used for examination of patients who are suspected to have or have a condition which could pose an airborne infection threat to other patients.
Space used for examination of patients with suspected contagious diseases.
Space used for gynecological examination of women.
Space used for examination of patients who conform to institutional criteria as being children, generally 1 year old to 20 years old.
Space used for examination of patients who are suspected to have or have a condition which makes them highly susceptible to infection.
Space used for the diagnosis and treatment of disorders of the foot, ankle and leg.
Space used for examination and holding of patients who are under custodial observation due to mental infirmity or judicial restraint.
Space used for taking measurement of patient height and weight.
Space used for placement of patients who need observation for a period of time under police supervision.
Spaces used for overnight patient care.
Space used for protective segregation of patients who have or are suspected of having contagious diseases to provide access control and environmental separation.
Space used for protective segregation of patients whose immune system is compromised to provide access control and environmental separation.
Space used in mental health units to provide controlled access to a seclusion room.

Space used for the Â“birthing processÂ” including pre-delivery preparation, delivery, and post delivery recovery. Where the acronym is Â“LDRÂ” the function does not include the post recovery hospital stay for the mother.
Space used for equipment and personnel charged with monitoring vital signs telemetry for an intensive care unit setting.
Space used for observation of newborn infants prior to placement in a newborn nursery or when their condition requires heightened attention or special intervention.
Space used for comprehensive and intensive care for neonates who have low birth weight, are very pre-mature, or who have other developmental and medical complications.
Space used for parking of specialized infant transport carts including those for transport to other facilities.
Space used for airborne infection isolation (AII) segregation of newborns.
Space used for observation of newborn infants prior to placement in a newborn nursery.
Space used for observation of newborn infants prior to placement in a newborn nursery or when their condition requires heightened attention or special intervention.
Space used for overnight patient care.
Space used for protective segregation of inpatients who have or are suspected of having contagious diseases.
Space used for the care of patients who are morbidly obese in an acute care inpatient nursing unit
Space used for care of patients whose health status requires highly focused and concentrated medical care services by staff with specialized training and skills.

extraAttributes.definitions: Space used for protective segregation of intensive care patients who have or are suspected of having contagious diseases.

level4.title: Patient Room, Intensive Care, Protective Environment Isolation

extraAttributes.definitions: Space used for protective segregation of intensive care patients whose immune system is compromised.
Space used for restrained isolation of patients for a short duration in a mental health setting
Space used in an inpatient setting where a patient care room must be capable of monitoring of vital signs
Space used for patient sleeping and care in an inpatient setting for a single patient.
Space used for protective segregation of patients whose immune system is compromised.
Used for segregation of patients who may pose a risk to themselves or others due to behavioral factors.
Space used for patient sleeping and care in a transitional or apartment setting.
Space used for patient sleeping and care in an inpatient setting for two patients.
Spaces used by multiple medical services to provide direct support for patient care.
Space used for storage of clean linen.
Space used for storage of clean supplies on carts or shelves.
Space used for the storage of clean supplies and clean linens and their preparation for patient use and for patient care support equipment such as icemakers and refrigerators.
Space used for meetings with patients and family members to discuss health status, learn health history, and provide information.
Space used for interviews and counseling with patients in an individual or group format.
Space used for storage of equipment such as surgical tables, accessories, carts, etc.
Space used for organized, active filing of physical patient charts, in a specially ordered and controlled environment
